title: How big can a black hole get? - Quora

response.answer_text: A black hole’s size (as defined by its Schwarzschild radius) is dependent on its mass, so how big a black hole gets is entirely dependent on how much material is around to feed into its mass. The biggest black holes in the universe are the supermassive black holes that live in the center of galaxies, which are thought to form alongside the galaxy rather than from the death of a star, reaching masses millions of times the mass of the sun. The largest of these are sometimes called ultra-massive black holes, and can be tens of billions of times the mass of the sun. About 30 candidate objects matching this description have been found lurking in the center of galaxies, surrounded by extraordinarily enormous and bright accretion disks of in-falling material:  (Image Credit: Space Engine[1]) The current largest candidate is TON 618, which has an estimated mass of 66 billion solar masses, which corresponds to a Schwarzschild radius of 1,300 AU, where 1 AU is the distance between the Earth and the Sun. For comparison, the aphelion of Pluto’s orbit (its furthest point from the sun), is just short of 50 AU—meaning, you could line up 26 entire Solar Systems end to end and that would stretch across the diameter of this black hole. Even the supermassive black hole, Sagittarius A*, which lives at the center of our own galaxy, is an estimated 0.16 AU in diameter. Here is a size comparison:  (Original Image Credit: Space Engine with modifications) The lower half of TON 618 in this computer generated image is obscured by its enormous accretion disk, which extends well outside the view of this image. Shown to scale is a set of small rings marking the outer perimeter of the Solar System’s Kuiper Belt, as well as the orbits of Neptune, Uranus, & Saturn. The Earth’s orbit would not even be the width of a pixel in this image. For further comparison, in the image below, the panel on the right could fit inside the blue ring in the image above:  (Original Image Credit: NASA/Caltech[2]with modifications) Sagittarius A* is shown to scale in the left panel on the top left. If we were to zoom in on that, this is what the sun would look like to scale:  (Original Image Credit: Wired/Paramount Pictures[3]with modifications) And lastly, here is a superimposed image of the Sun and the Earth to scale:  (Image Credit: NASA/GSFC[4]) That being said, TON 618’s mass hasn’t been as precisely measured as other ultra-massive black holes, such as H1821+643, which has a mass of 30 billion solar masses, and a corresponding radius of 575 AU, a little less than half the estimated radius of TON 618. This is the same order of magnitude, however, and so TON 618 is likely pretty close to the upper bound for how massive a black hole can get. Because these ultra-massive black holes form along side their parent galaxy, how big they get depends on the amount of material in the galaxy. Black holes can only get larger by accreting material or merging with another black hole. The observed distribution of mass in the most massive galaxies we can see suggest that once a black hole grows to about [math]10^{10}[/math] solar masses, the region of gas surrounding it is producing so much radiation that it drives an outward flow of material in the galactic nucleus, cutting off its own supply of gas. Once accretion stops, the only way for the black hole to gain in mass is if the galactic nucleus becomes supplied with more material through mergers with other galaxies. Galactic mergers could raise that upper bound to something closer to [math]10^{11}[/math] solar masses. Since TON 618 is still so optically bright, that means that it still has its accretion disk, which means that it is still growing in mass, but is likely towards the tail end, as its accretion disk is glowing with the brightness of 140 trillion suns, which is a truly absurd amount of radiation. Accretion will likely stop for this black hole within the next 100 million years, at which point it will lose its accretion disk and no longer be optically visible, aside from short-lived bursts of radiation from a star or cloud passing too close. This suggests that its unlikely we’d actually be able to see the most massive black holes in the universe, which could potentially lie in the 100 billion solar mass range. Footnotes[1] Space Engine - the universe simulator[2] Orbit Comparisons - NASA Spitzer Space Telescope[3] How Building a Black Hole for Interstellar Led to an Amazing Scientific Discovery[4] https://images.nasa.gov/details-GSFC_20171208_Archive_e001660.html

Theoretically, unlimited. In reality it depends on the mass available to incorporate into the BH. Currently the largest one found is about 17 billion solar masses. Its Event Horizon is larger than our solar system (out to Neptune). I have no doubt there are others out there (maybe beyond the visible Universe horizon) that are even larger, but we have almost no chance to detect and measure them. Since the Universe is expanding the proximity of BHs to available matter is lessening every day, meaning that many BHs will not have anything to incorporate and increase their own mass.

(Note: If we are dealing with event horizons of black holes, then I may state that Astronomers have found black holes with event horizons ranging from 6 miles to the size of our solar system. There is a separate question in Quora that deals with event horizons of black holes. Please see: https://www.quora.com/What-is-the-size-of-a-black-hole) Standard black hole classification falls into four or five categories: i) Ordinary stellar mass black holes weigh-in at approximately 10 to 100 times the mass of our sun (1 SM 1 Solar mass). ii) The intermediate mass black holes have masses below 100,000 SM. iii) Supermassive holes are anything above that extending into the millions and even billions of times the mass of our sun. Anything up to 10 billion SM may be described as Supermassive black holes. iv) A few black holes seem to exceed even the description of Supermassive holes and these are referred to as Ultra-massive black holes. TN610 at 66 billion SM is one such. v) Another hypothetical class of black holes is primordial black holes, which would have formed out of density fluctuations in the early universe. Generally, they would have been so tiny that they can only be properly described using quantum mechanics. But black holes evaporate through a process called Hawking Radiation. How quickly a black hole evaporates depends on its mass: the less massive a black hole, the more quickly it evaporates. For a primordial black hole to have survived to the present day, it would have to contain a few billion tons of mass, with a radius comparable to that of an atomic nucleus. There’s much we still don’t know about how these biggest holes got so big, but gaining mass through these accretion disks clearly plays a prominent role. It seems however that accretion disks become increasingly unstable the bigger the supermassive black hole becomes. This instability appears to reach a breaking point causing the disk to completely fragment and collapse into stars in their own rights. As to how much is this breaking point might be, I have seen several guesstimates in the several august journals ranging between 10billion SM and 50 billion SM. In 2016, the Science daily stated thus: “Until now, the biggest supermassive black holes -- those with masses around 10 billion times that of our sun -- have been found at the cores of very large galaxies in regions loaded with other large galaxies. The current record holder, discovered in the Coma Cluster by the UC Berkeley team in 2011, tips the scale at 21 billion solar masses and is listed in the Guinness Book of World Records.” You can see that in 2019, we are unable to accept this statement TN610 is one Ultra-Massive black hole that at 66 billion SM defies description. The difficulty here in assigning a number stems from the fact that we do not know much about Supermassive/Ultramassive black holes even when we know that they have a size limitation

Here’s the biggest one we’ve found:  S5 0014+81. It’s the largest black hole ever discovered and is heavier than our Sun by 40 billion times This black hole has a radius of just under 119 billion kilometers, a diameter of about 236 billion km. The tiny red dot in the middle is the size of our solar system including Pluto. The original ‘star’ S5 0014+81 should have had a diameter of 55,679,280,000,000,000 kilometers. 56 quadrillion kms. Or 1804 Parsecs - 5885 Light years. That’s 5 times thicker than the Milky Way. And that’s on the outside: From Marios Christodoulou and Carlo Rovelli, How big is a black hole?. How big is the black hole at the center of our galaxy? It's about 2 million kilometers across. That's pretty big - but the orbit of Mercury is 60 times bigger. This black hole is old, roughly a billion years old. And here's the cool part: it's been growing on the inside all this time! On the inside, it can hold a million solar systems! Its volume is about 10**34 cubic kilometers! And it's growing at a rate of about 10**25 cubic kilometers per year! This black hole will last a long time before it evaporates due to Hawking radiation. Christodolou and Rovelli estimate how big its volume will get before this happens. And it gets really big - bigger than the current-day observable universe! …people falling into the black hole will not have time to do anything fun inside. They will hit the singularity in a short time. Very very roughly speaking, the problem is not the shortage of space inside the black hole, it's the shortage of time. If you fall into the black hole at the center of our galaxy, it will be about 1 minute, at most, before you hit the singularity. You will not get to see most of the space inside the black hole! The singularity is not in the 'middle' of the black hole - it's in your future.

Thanks for asking. Despite the large variety of answers, this is a rather simple question. There is no theoretical limit on how big a black hole can get. There may be some practical limitations. For example, there are theories that after a black hole reaches about 50 billion solar masses, it may have difficulty creating an accretion disk from which more mass is obtain, but it won’t prevent the merger with another black hole or the consumption of an object moving directly toward it. And, there is the practical limit of not being able to consume more mass than what is in the gravitationally bound galaxy cluster in which it resides. EDITORIAL. This question with its 70 answers illustrates the problem with Cosmology questions/answers in Quora. Most of the answers are flat out wrong, have serious errors, or don’t answer the question. Many are simply opinions with no scientific backing. Others use the question as means to propose their own pet theories — often philosophies with little or no scientific reasoning and ignoring observations and experimental evidence. And, then we have the answers that are simply a cut and paste from other sources, but often out of context. Most of the Cosmology questions on Quora aren’t that hard. Black holes, universe expansion, CMB, and expansion of the universe are relatively simple concepts, especially at the level of questions being asked. Unfortunately, most of the answers are wrong or misleading. Quora should be a place you go for answers. For science, that means facts, not opinions.

The problem with questions like this is that the scale of the answer is most difficult to put into something that the human mind can appreciate at all levels. One of my instructors always put large numbers into something that we could see, feel or imagine and that allowed every listener, from top of the class to the lowly individual (or small number) at the bottom. For example he would offer that a “billion seconds is really 30 years” and to explain a TRILLION seconds on the same scale “it is 30,000 years”. (Actually “31,688 and a smidgen years” but not important to the example so forgive his rounding error.) However, “so many sun masses” or “so many trillions of miles or kilometers” answers somehow lose their scale to most people. It should be understood that black holes are huge amount of mass more than they are distance alone. Two black holes combining only double their mass rather than become twice as large in size. Try this example to better grasp the mass of a black hole of extreme size: A black hole consisting of the MASS of the earth would be SMALLER than the nail on your little finger, but with the same gravitational force. Hope that helps to make sense out of how much mass must be in LARGE black holes.

It really depends on how much matter these is in the vicinity of the black hole for it to consume. Contrary to popular belief, black holes are not big vacuum cleaners. They act just like any other object with mass. The amount of gravitational influence a black hole has is solely dependent on its mass. If our sun was a black hole it would be about 6 kms across but the planets of the solar system would still orbit where they are. But if the mass was greater, then we will probably be in an orbit closer that we are now, proportional to the mass of the black hole. Black holes can only grow when they feed. Super-massive black holes, millions to billions of times the mass of the sun occur at the center of most, if not all, galaxies. Such monstrously large black holes have existed since the universe was very young however, it still remains somewhat of a mystery how these giants could have grown so big in the relatively short amount of time they had to form. Early in the history of the universe, massive stars were relatively common because there was plenty of molecular gas and dust clouds around and they were tightly packed but these stars lived very short lives. Around 10 million years is the average life span of these massive stars and these are the stars that will likely end up as black holes or neutron stars. The common belief is that the early universe was a lot denser than it is now and there was plenty of matter drifting around. Because the early black holes were able to form very quickly, they were able to attract a lot matter such as gas clouds and even stars that drift too close, thereby growing quickly. As the density of the matter within the gravitational influence of the black hole begins runs out, the black hole slowly become dormant until something drifts too close and thereby gets pulled into the black hole, forever lost………………………………………. It is thought that this below is what happens to a star that gets too close to a black hole. After the star got too close it was caught in the gravitational influence of the black hole. The white portion is the matter being heated as it swirls around the accretion disk and the black dot in the middle is the event horizon. Once anything passes beyond the event horizon, it is forever gone as even light cannot escape once it crosses the event horizon.  Image of what a feeding black hole would probably look like

To me, galaxies began their lives as single masses of fusion powered plasma. How big the black hole gets boils down to how big the initial mass was and how fast the mass was spinning when it was created in the collision of two objects better known as the big bang. Some galaxies weren't spinning at all and created elliptical ones where the matter was released directly from the center. This situation hides the black hole with the visible light that the cooling matter releases. Spiral galaxies such as our own use centrifugal force to distribute the matter into a giant disk with a bulbous center initially. Eventually, the center separates and the black hole is born leaving the stars and their corresponding solar systems to be created with the remaining disk of plasma. Based on a couple of factors, the center could constitute most of the matter of the galaxy or could end up like ours in which the black hole is only a relatively small percentage of the galaxy.

How big can a black hole get ? Thanks Phil for asking, this is one of my favourite subjects. The question of Black hole minimum and maximum dimensions (radius) is more a question about the choice of definition. Must we define a black hole by its physical reality (science doesn’t know) or by its none physical outer not observable boundary (science does know) ? To start with the last option : the Schwarzschild radius only depends on its mass and can be well calculated once we know its mass. The two most massive black holes we have observed indirectly and measured have a mass of about 50 billion sun masses. According Schwarzschild radius equations they have a radius of about 212317 sun radius, a staggering 148 trillion metre (148 billion km). There is no reason to assume they will ever stop accreting mass, so they will grow in mass and will grow bigger. ….. But as mentioned above, a Schwarzschild radius is meaningless as an accurate physical radius. There is nothing there, at the Schwarzschild radius, there is no matter and the temperature is almost 0 Kelvin. Way deep inside, hidden from sight, is its mass, being extremely dense and extremely hot. 99,99999……9 % of a black hole’s Schwarzschild radius volume is just empty space. According science this hot and dense centre mass of a black hole has no radius, meaning that when scientists try to calculate it (with tried and trusted theory) they find an infinity. Finding infinities is disastrous for scientists, meaning something is terribly wrong with their equations. When such a black hole increases in mass, its calculated radius is still meaningless infinitely small or big. So there’s where science today still is with black holes accreting mass all the time : a meaningless big radius that is steadily growing on the one side and a meaningless infinitely small radius on the other side that is neither growing nor shrinking. I have developed a theory of quantum gravity, outside the tried and trusted theory, that opens a different perspective about the physical radius of any black hole. I have formulated two formulas to calculate its limits in between certain uncertainties. I have called it the “Whitney Limit” and that’s a Dutch absurdist joke for “knowing” what we cannot know. Whitney is a girlfriend that I tried to explain my theory and while trying, I got the idea to use her name for the limit she couldn’t understand. When I calculate the Whitney Limit for the two most massive black holes we know, about 50 billion sun masses, I get a radius of about 0,05 sun radius and that is only 34,8 million metres or 34800 km. That is somewhere in between Neptune and Saturn. That is in my opinion how big the biggest known black holes did get and they are growing millimetre by millimetre as we speak.

The most massive black hole observed is: TON 618 - Wikipedia  https://aminoapps.com/c/space/page/blog/ton-618-biggest-quasar/n5kJ_wxzFLuMX0RK0BNxevnjLbEr3vb3EBz  This has an estimate mass of 66 billion solar masses, and a radius of 1300 AU. That means 1300 times the distance from the Earth to the sun. It would take light 15 days to cross the distance of the diameter. I found this black hole list on List of most massive black holes. The list is updated fairly regularly, so future readers may find this is no longer the largest known. Now there is a theoretical limit of 50 billion solar masses. Which makes Ton 618 black hole a bit of a mystery. But that limit is based on the super massive black hole being unable to stream hydrogen from a star without a majority of the mass radiating away. It is still possible for a black hole to continue to gain mass slowly, and to merge with other black holes. So the most likely explanation is two extremely large super massive blackholes merged together. Also the 50 billion solar mass limit is really more of an order of magnitude calculation, so it is not unbelievable that it could be off by a factor of 2. But observation tells us the 50 billion solar mass limit is close to correct. Now if you had a way to bring in more black holes to merge, the only limit in black hole mass is just how many black holes you had available. An interesting side-note, it has been show if black holes could absorb dark matter, and dark matter was uniformly distributed in a galaxy, we would expect black holes at least 5 billion solar masses to rapidly grow to about 500 billion solar masses as they absorb dark matter in the core of the galaxy. That would correspond to a black hole about half a light year across. But no black holes that large have been observed, giving us yet another mystery about dark matter.

Pretty damn big. Monster Black Hole Is Biggest Ever Found By Elizabeth Howell, Space.com Contributor | November 28, 2012 01:01pm ET   This image shows the disk galaxy NGC 1277, as seen by the Hubble Space Telescope. The small, flattened galaxy has one of the biggest central super-massive black holes ever found in its center, the equivalent of 17 billion suns. Credit: NASA / ESA / Andrew C. Fabian / Remco C. E. van den Bosch (MPIA) Astronomers have discovered what may be the most massive black hole ever known in a small galaxy about 250 million light-years from Earth, scientists say. The supermassive black hole has a mass equivalent to 17 billion suns and is located inside the galaxy NGC 1277 in the constellation Perseus. It makes up about 14 percent of its host galaxy's mass, compared with the 0.1 percent a normal black hole would represent, scientists said. "This is a really oddball galaxy," said study team member Karl Gebhardt of the University of Texas at Austin in a statement. "It's almost all black hole. This could be the first object in a new class of galaxy-black hole systems." Advertisement The giant black hole is about 11 times as wide as the orbit of Neptune around our sun, researchers said. The mass is so far above normal that the scientists took a year to double-check and submit their research paper for publication, according to the study's lead author, Remco van den Bosch. "The first time I calculated it, I thought I must have done something wrong. We tried it again with the same instrument, then a different instrument," van den Bosch, an astronomer at Germany's Max Planck Institute for Astronomy, told Space.com. "Then I thought, 'Maybe something else is happening.'" [Strangest Black Holes in the Universe]

That’s an interesting question. It would depend on the nature of how large stars can get, as black holes are the remnants of collapsed stars no longer actively undergoing nuclear fusion to produce light etc. It also depends on the rate at which the black hole would continue to engulf matter such as star matter, as this would result in an increase in mass. Black holes can consume thousands of solar masses of star matter, resulting in an active state known as Quasars:  The largest black hole is in the order of 40 billion solar masses, although this may not be a limit to their size. Eventually all the matter in the Universe may have been engulfed by black holes, such that that is all that is left. Once this occurs, the black holes would start losing mass through ‘Hawking radiation’, although this would take a vast and unimaginable period of time. Black holes also gain mass through merging with other black holes. Hope this helps.

There is a theoretical lower mass for black holes, but it is not clear how big they could get before some kind of limit is reached. To put it into perspective, stellar mass black holes would be several solar masses. Think something about the size of a planet but with a mass of 5 or 6 times that of our sun. Supermassive black holes are found at the centers of large galaxies like ours. Sagittarius A*, the one at the center of our galaxy, is about 4 million solar masses. The one at the center of Andromeda is considerably larger, perhaps between 30–200 million solar masses. There is growing evidence of intermediate mass black holes, i.e., those between stellar mass and supermassive varieties. But that is nothing in the grand scale of things. The black hole named TON 618 is estimated to be 66 billion solar masses. To put this into perspective, this is more massive than some galaxies. This is probably the largest black hole ever discovered. But it is possible for the black hole at the center of galaxy IC 1101 to be even more massive. How massive can they get? Who knows. Perhaps there is an upper limit to how much gravitational energy you can concentrate in such a confined space.

To the best of our understanding, there is no limit. Any matter or energy that crosses the event horizon of a black hole is incorporated into the black hole. The event horizon expands to accommodate the extra mass. As to how big a black hole can get, the biggest known are at the centres of galaxies and can have a mass millions of times that of the sun. As the Universe evolves, black holes are likely to grow, so that galactic-mass black holes are likely to form. There is an opposing process known as Hawking Radiation (see Hawking radiation - Wikipedia) through which black holes 'evaporate', but this is an extremely slow process for stellar-mass and larger black holes, with growth through infalling material (dust, gas, the occasional star) likely to dominate for billions (likely trillions) of years. As the Universe expands, distant galaxies will disappear over the horizon of the observable Universe, where the rate of Hubble expansion of space (see https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hubble%27s_law) exceeds the speed of light. In due course, it is believed that only the Local Group of galaxies will be observable and be able to interact with each other. Within the Local Group, gravity dominates over the more general Hubble expansion and galaxies within it are predicted to stay together, indeed with a long term tendency to merge. This suggests a likely upper limit to the size of black holes that are likely to form - a galactic cluster like the Local Group. Although, so far as is known, there is no theoretical upper limit.

Brief answer: The biggest black hole is the central black hole in every galaxy. Due to natural law, the natural mechanisms spontaneously regulate the size of the central black hole to the oscillation range of the mass state matter --- energy state matter transformation critical mass. More explanation: The biggest black hole is the central black holes in the centre of every galaxy. Due to natural law regulation, matter contact congregation cannot go over too much in the range of the oscillation in the dynamic balance of the size of the mass state matter – energy state matter transformation critical mass. This mass congregation is the concentrative – dissipative structure (central black hole) that converts the positive thermodynamic entropy into the negative thermodynamic entropy. There is the natural spontaneous dynamic balancing mechanisms at work to regulate the size of the central black holes: the bigger, the more violent the mass state matter to be transformed into energy state matter and be cast out into the vast space; smaller than the mass state matter – energy state matter transformation critical mass, the mass state matter – energy state matter transformation stops and no mass will be cast out, and in the meantime nothing can stop it from drawing in mass to feed its size growth. Everything is a fair game, including the smaller black holes. Two or more central black hole can merge though sooner or later the size will be spontaneously regulated to the oscillating range of the mass state matter – energy state matter transformation critical mass. This natural positive boosting and negative restraining mechanisms that alternatively taking over the process is the reason there cannot be any Big Crunch or Big Bang in the universe --- natural laws not allow. This periodic oscillation between the positive boosting and negative restraining mechanisms alternatively taking over the control of the process in the central black hole is a long period to us that makes us think some central black holes are permanently quiet while some others are permanently noisy (with their two opposite jets of light beams), actually they are just in their different phases in the oscillation period. Therefore, if you cannot see the quiet ones that don’t jet out light beams and may be blocked out of view by thick dust clouds, it does not mean it is not there in the centre of that galaxy. It just has to be there due the natural law that defined the gravity of mass.

You can calculate the size of a black hole with the Schwarzschild radius: r=2GM/c^2 The radius only depends on the mass, all other numbers in this formula are natural constants. That means every mass that can be kept within its Schwarzschild radius is a black hole. One would assume that you need a very high mass density to achieve a black hole, but in fact that is not true. The Observable universe has a Schwarzschild radius of approximately 13.7 billion light years. Its actual diameter is 45.7 billion light-years. Shrinking the distances between stars by a factor of four would still leave the universe mostly being empty space — but it would change the whole universe into a black hole. Note that this wouldn’t change much for anyone in the observable universe; only nobody from the outside could look into it, since no light could escape from it.

A black hole has unbelievable gravity pull, and so it can get bigger by eating massive bodies within it range of centripetal pull. However astronomy has not reported huge black holes that get uncontrollably bigger and bigger in abnormal ways. The theory that the universe would one day collapse into a singularity and restart another universe, cannot be correct. The point is that galaxies are separated by incredible distances and there is no physical reason why they can get so near to one another that there is a big crunch. My theory of the origin of the universe predicts that the CCC theory of Penrose has no scientific explanation, The accelerated expansion of the universe is another evidence for this statement..

At least theoretically, there is no limit to how big (the event horizon) can be. It just depends on the mass. In a rich cluster of galaxies, where galaxies can collide with each other on a frequent basis (using astronomical time scales to define “frequent”), it is conceivable that a black hole might eventually acquire a substantial fraction of the mass of the cluster. Since such clusters contain up to hundreds or thousands of trillions of stars, that could make the mass of a black hole a trillion or more solar masses, in which case the radius of the event horizon could be in excess of 3 trillion kilometers (3 km being the radius of a one-solar-mass’ event horizon), or about 20 thousand AUs, which is about 1/3 of a light year. And although 20 thousand AUs is a large distance, it isn’t as big as the radius of the Oort Cloud (estimated to be about 30 thousand AUs), so although it’s a lot bigger than the orbit of Pluto (which is a mere 40 AUs), it isn’t as big as the entire Solar System. Btw, supermassive black holes are not created by the collapse of stellar masses, as implied in the case of the “star” that turned into black hole S5 0014+81. The most massive stars are only about two to three hundred solar masses (and perhaps not even that massive), so supermassive black holes are formed by the collapse of large amounts of gas in the centers of forming galaxies, and grow by collisions with black holes from other galaxies, when galaxies in clusters collide with each other. So any estimate of the supposed original size of that nonexistent star is meaningless.

There is no upper limit to how massive a black hole can get, and thus no upper limit to it’s size (the radius of it’s event horizon) either. In one way, the available mass in the universe puts an upper limit, but no black hole will ever each anywhere near this mass, since the universe appears to be expanding forever. The most massive black holes “known” have masses of tens of billions suns. One interesting quirk with black holes is that the radius of their event horizons is proportional to it’s mass. So twice the mass means twice the radius, and so 1/8 the density. So supermassive black holes aren’t more dense than planets, and if the black hole was large enough (which means bizarrely large), it’s density would approach that of vacuum.

Black Holes have a size maximum size limit of 50 billion times the mass of our sun (1-solar mass (Мʘ) ) The solar mass (Мʘ) is a standard unit of mass in astronomy, used to indicate the masses of other stars, as well as clusters, nebulae and galaxies. It is equal to the mass of the Sun, which is 1.9855 X 10³⁰ kg (4.4 X 10³⁰ lbs). Source https://www-newscientist-com.cdn.ampproject.org/v/s/www.newscientist.com/article/dn28647-black-holes-have-a-size-limit-of-50-billion-suns/amp/?amp_js_v=0.1&usqp=mq331AQECAEoAQ%3D%3D#origin=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.google.com&prerenderSize=1&visibilityState=prerender&paddingTop=54&p2r=0&horizontalScrolling=0&csi=1&aoh=15488810140762&viewerUrl=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.google.com%2Famp%2Fs%2Fwww.newscientist.com%2Farticle%2Fdn28647-black-holes-have-a-size-limit-of-50-billion-suns%2Famp%2F&history=1&storage=1&cid=1&cap=swipe%2CnavigateTo%2Ccid%2Cfragment%2CreplaceUrl&highlight=%7B%22s%22%3A%5B%22Black%20holes%20have%20a%20size%20limit%20of%2050%20billion%20suns.%22%5D%7D

That’s a great question Phil. I remember reading somewhere that there is an upper limit for the size of a black hole, and it is somewhere around 50 billion solar masses. The size of such a black hole would be thousands of times larger than our solar system. How’s that for a scary thought! The reason why there is an upper limit, and this is theoretical, but supported by mathematics, is that a black hole at that upper limit is growing to that size because it is gobbling up material. The accretion disk of a black hole of that size would be so energetic, that eventually this energy would drive away all of the other things in the vicinity of the black hole. So the black hole is in a sense starving itself by getting that big.

I am answering this question primarily because you asked, since this not a question that I feel I know enough about to be confident in my answer. Stated simply, I am not aware of there being a limit on the size of black holes (and so I assume there is no limit). See Black hole - Wikipedia Once the black hole has a mass that is larger than the moon, the rate of its evaporation is slower than its rate of growth from absorbing background radiation of space and so it would seem to be stable. I am not aware of a mechanism for a larger size of black holes to become unstable. However, I don’t know much about black holes, and I am just a patent agent with a Ph.D. in physics.

It is dog eat dog. As the black holes gobble up more and more matter their gravity becomes overwhelming and two black holes collide and become one black hole. This will continue for billions of years until all the matter in the universe will be contained in two supermassive black holes. Eventually they will attract each other together with the biggest one ‘eating’ the slightly smaller one. This may go over the threshold of a black hole and cause a chain reaction that makes the black hole explode with the power of a billion billion supernovas. This is the big bang. Civilisations will rise and fall in each epic lasting billions of years. You and me may have existed over and over again thousands of times looking exactly the same with the same life. Only when the civilisation becomes so knowledge and powerful that they can stop a black hole by exploding it will the epic stay in position for ever, a new future never repeated before would then be happening. I don't know I'm not that good but whoever decided the sise of the big bang should have the basic math info at hand if he is correct. Just take that critical mass that caused the big bang and factor in the spin in a galaxy energy and Walla a mathematician with more time on his hand then me can do that math and we will know how big a black hole can get. As I understand it there is no real limit. When mass gets close to the event horizon it is pulled in. So in theory if you could somehow cause all the mass of the universe to slowly get near the blackhole, then it would slowly get more and more massive. Start by taking all the black holes in the universe and aim them towards a single spot. If all their speeds are set so they reach the same place, at the same time, then they will all merge into one super massive blackhole. Then start aiming all the other stars towards that same point, to arrive just after the blackhole merger. You could end up with a blackhole with the mass of the universe. …now how big would that be? Big enough.

Q: How big can a black hole get? Interesting question. There are many answers already. There really isn’t a size limit to a black hole. There does appear to be a limit to how much a black hole can ingest all at once. Old Quasars are essentially very active super massive black holes. They are very far away, so their size is usually hard to approximate, but they are so bright that they shine brighter than some galaxies. They are estimate to be 1 to 2 light years across. However, that would include the active material being ejected. But, in theory, as long as material can fall directly into the black hole, it will absorb it.

A black hole can and will ‘eventually’ hold all the mass of our universe, i can’t predict which one if any of those that exist and has been named such as Ton 618, will be the one through its lifetime from now to the ‘last’ black hole will only merge with black holes smaller than itself, hence getting to keep its name ☺ But the largest ‘size’ a black hole can get, is the ‘size’ of our entire universe

There is no physical limit to the size of a black hole. However due to how matter is distributed, only a very limited amount of matter is available to a black hole. So billions of solar masses is possible. Trillions not. If there was a black hole out there that was significantly more heavy then the total amount of observed matter, the observable universe might collapse. So there is a limit beyond which the universe cannot exists. This value is much bigger then what is possible due to matter distribution.

At the moment we do not have calculations, but we do know that in general it is limited. Universe is too young to predict that with accuracy. One feature of our Universe is that it is flat. Because of this any body in Cosmos is not spherical. At some point this makes leakage in Black Hole on South and North poles. The other thing is rotation, all bodies eventually start to rotate. Coriolis and centrifugal force are causes for death for others big stars (like white dwarf). And the last is asymmetrical eating. What we see in far space near Black Hole, the matter does not fall straight to its center, but always rotate around until in gets behind the event horizon. This queue has different thickness. Also many planets dragged to the Black Hole are overheating and they may produce huge blast just on one side. Not known, but it may destroy Black Hole.

Great question ! We have a super massive black hole in the center of our galaxy, the Milk Way! Fear not, or at least try not to, as some astronomers state the a galaxy formation may need a black hole in the center to pull things together. Nevertheless, getting back on track, our buddy SMBH has an estimated 44 million km in diameter, and has the mass of over 4 million Suns. Pretty big, and there are bigger ones.

The largest galactic black holes run over ten billion solar masses. But there is an overall balancing effect in the interaction between a black hole and its galaxy. A black hole consumes a certain amount of material and also blasts a large percentage out into the galactic halo, thus decentralizing the galaxy. There is a balance in the “circle of life.” The supermassive black hole in Perseus, galaxy NGC 1277 is 17 billion solar masses. Some are even larger. Another example is S5 0014+81

The largest known black hole is S5 0014+813 with 40 billion solar masses. The oldest was formed 690 million years after the Big Bang that's 800 million times more massive than the sun. They means the way they grow is principally gas, dust, movie stars, planets, or colliding along with other black holes. Whenever that occurs the aftermath is HUGE.

I don’t know if there’s anything that constrains upper limit, and will follow the question for further answers. There are enormous black holes, a billion times the mass of the sun, see for instance Supermassive black hole - Wikipedia I think since space in general is pretty empty, it would take a long time for a black hole to grow just because there isn’t much stuff around that would go into it.

I can’t think of a reason a black hole cannot add more mass no matter how large it is. There are three possibilities. 1. The black hole becomes so large something snaps and its gravity sucks it into itself and it becomes the kind of singularity from which our universe arrose. 2. It continues adding mass and grows. 3. it reaches a point at which something shifts and it explodes. I don’t think anyone has observed 1 or 3. So it must be 2 so far as we know today. That is unless the “Big Bang” was a case of 1.

How big can a black hole get? I don’t know if there’s any limit at all, Phil. They can certainly get very big, like Andy Fletcher said. And I have a sneaking suspicion that once upon a time the whole universe was a black hole. That tops S5 0014+81. However we don’t live in a black hole now. So maybe it was too big. Like I said, I don’t know. Sorry,
response.upvotes: Answer requested by Phil Cerza and Patrick Greer

response.answer_text: Without getting into actual weights & measurements, a Black Hole will consume all matter within our universe of regular matter. And in order to keep the Cosmos in balance, a White Hole will do the same with dark matter. Then a Black Hole will annihilate a White Hole, and the 2 will return back into Nothingness from whence they came. Below is a diagram of a complete life cycle of a (+/-) Binary Universe System from Nothingness, to formation of regular matter and dark matter, and then back into Nothingness:

The Schwarzschild radius depends on mass. If a body shrinks happens to have its mass inside that radius, it’s a black hole. So, take the mass of the known universe, and do the math. In practice, stuff are far away from rach other, and from far away, a black hole is like any other mass, so being a black hole alone won’t make it grow. Quasars, huge elliptical galaxies are a place to look for interesting examples.

A black hole is never very big. It is a point in space that has infinite density of matter. (In reality we just have no theory that applies as something approaches a black hole.) The mass of a black hole can be enormous, and the event horizon around a black hole can get very big, but the black hole itself is never more than a point.

The Event Horizons of black holes are determined by the mass of the hole. A hole with infinite mass might have an infinitely big event horizon. If things can not get smaller than superstrings then the center of a black hole may be a bundle of superstings or other small stuff. If this is the case then the core of a black hole could in theory be any size.

So-called ultramassive black holes (UMBHs), which are at least ten times the size of supermassive black holes, appear to have a theoretical upper limit of around 50 billion solar masses, as anything above this slows growth down to a crawl (the slowdown tends to start around 10 billion solar masses? Very, very big but black holes are not limitless in size or mass!

There are some astronomical papers that suggest that black holes cannot accrete matter once they get to be about 10 billion solar masses. This has to do with the dynamics of accretion disks. However, they can still get bigger by colliding with other black holes. So imagine a 10 bsm black hole colliding with another 10 bsm black hole - that ought to make some gravity waves!

Size does matter, and even black holes cannot grow indefinitely. According to a new piece of research, black holes at the center of galaxies can only reach a mass of about 50 billion times that of the Sun before they disrupt their feeding cycle and stop gaining weight. How Big Can A Black Hole Get? | IFLScience http://www.iflscience.com/space/black-holes-have-maximum-size/

In Theory it can also grow to infinity. Some astronomers have imagined that our universe could be a black hole (even if there are some incongruities in this hypothesis). It depends on how much mass it manages to accumulate inside the Black Hole Note: English is not my first language, so I am really sorry for grammar errors and expression, so please feel free to use the "suggest edit" to help correct me. Thanks!

As strange physics is, there is no way to know! As far as we know, we are living in one now, and it is the universe! Isn't is strange that the beginning point of the Big Bang Theory and a black hole seem the same, a very massive singularity?I None of this is impossible to prove wrong!

Therotically there is no limit on how much mass a blackhole can have. If it keeps feeding on surrounding matter,stars,blackholes then it will keep on growing. So far TON 619 is the most massive blackhole discovered, however rest assured as our techniques and understanding gets better, soon we will find more massive blackholes.

The question has many answers, but fundamentally depends of how much matter can swallow from surrounding areas. Considering the Big Bang theory, I guess there is a point where it will stop and expand, I would say when the matter of the actual known universe is collapsed in a singularity it will be enough to produce an expansion.

It would depend on if the black hole has matter to suck in because the more matter the black hole sucks in the bigger its event horizon gets. The limit I would guess be based on how much material it sucks in. With no matter to suck in then the black hole would slowly get smaller emitting Hawking radiation.

We do not know. There seems to be a critical point similar to the nuclear stability of a star, where pressure from impact of incoming materials balances the pressure from heat and other radiation leaving the star. It is possible that we have underestimated the quantity and the effects of Hawking radiation in balancing the pressure from the impact of materials entering a black hole, similarly explaining that there might be a point of starvation at which a mature black hole loses its stability and explodes. Other factors point in the same direction; the massive amounts of hydrogen consumed in fusion by all the stars in a galaxy have to come from somewhere. The obvious source are black holes evaporating the equivalent amounts of energy, dark energy and possibly dark matter, later reconstituted into sub particles and particles on up to hydrogen, the main fuel for all the stars. Maybe we will know a little more tomorrow, with the release of the new black hole images.

The largest a Black Hole can get is all of the matter in the entire universe. And only if gravity wins but as has been shown, the universe is still expanding so the size is determined by the mass of local group the Black Hole is in or other groups that it might be able to attract.

The largest known black hole is S5 0014+813 with 40 billion solar masses. The oldest was formed 690 million years after the Big Bang that's 800 million times more massive than the sun. They way how they grow is mainly gas, dust, stars, planets, or even colliding with other black holes. When that happens the aftermath is HUGE.

A black hole can and will ‘eventually’ hold all the mass of our universe, i can’t predict which one if any of those that exist and has been named such as Ton 618, will be the one through its lifetime from now to the ‘last’ black hole will only merge with black holes smaller than itself, hence getting to keep its name ☺ But the largest ‘size’ a black hole can get, is the ‘size’ of our entire universe

response.answer_text: Stellar-mass black holes are typically in the range of 10 to 100 solar masses, while the supermassive black holes at the centers of galaxies can be millions or billions of solar masses. The supermassive black hole at the center of the Milky Way, Sagittarius A*, is 4.3 million solar masses.

Bigger than the known universe… well that’s the present day estimate. but I’m skeptical that there is enough matter in the universe to make a black hole the size of the known universe.. But If the universe is truly infinite.. well that changes everything..

How much room you got? Theoretically, it is unlimited. Practically, it is limited by the density of material in the universe over time, and the time allowed for formation. I don’t know that anyone has a good estimate of that but I may be wrong.

I don’t know if there is any limit whatsoever. Black holes merge with other black holes and become bigger black holes. There are those who believe, that at some point, our universe will collapse again, after inflation stops, and all black holes will become one
As big as all the matter in our Universe. Of course, then when it reached absolute zero, it would explode into a new universe. Funny, but in physics very hot and very cold are surprisingly similar.

No one can accurately answer that question because, while undoubtedly there is a limit to the size that black holes can grow just as there is with planets and stars, no one truly knows. Not yet, that is.

Black hole (BH) is only a mathematical concept. Mathemagicians create objects which don't have representation in nature. There are no perfect lines, squares or circles in the universe. There aren't infinitely dense objects either. There aren't negative values in nature, by the way - all parameters are “positive”, even if we talk about antimatter. So, black holes don't exist.

The maximum possible mass of a blackhole is the mass of the universe. Cosmologists are not sure if the universe will ever stop expanding and start collapsing, but if it does, the universe will form 1 single huge black hole at the end of its current life.
The current thinking is that the limit of size for a black hole is about 50 billion times the size of our Sun. At that volume it would likely have consumed all the material within its range.
We do not know how big black holes can get. There is no known limit to the size of black holes.

As big as the scientist says it can get. We can’t prove it. Before you type an insult please comment on: Can we use a directional indicator gyroscope, with the latitude nut set to zero compensation, to prove Earth's rotation?

Black holes, dwarf stars and the rest of this nonsense is pure fiction. “Scientists” can speculate as to why but the “how” will never be confirmed. When was the last time a constellation chart had this footnote: “The 4th star from the left became a black hole!” If it hasn’t occurred in thousands of years in our universe, why would it occur somewhere else? My point is, why bother? Spend the money and time here on earth where reality exists and good can come from REAL efforts. “Learning” about the universe clutters the brain and gives Leftism/Democrat nonsense to likewise enter.

TOP scientists tell us that there is no limit ( so far as they know ), some have suggested that there IS a limit at which point a Big Bang can occur, creating a whole new universe,…. but so far THIS is only speculation ……
“Big” is a not existing notion, since Albert Einstein’s Theory of RELATIVITY, and especially after my exciting new Topological Model of the Universe.
No one knows. we still have not even gained a clear enough picture of a real black yet to know information like that. We have enough evidence to know they should exist, but no physical visual proof.

Consider the extremes: little sun blacks to invisible with heat chaos inside or a gigantic sun snuffs out all nuclear reactions in itself but is not cold inside as is the infinite vaccum. Remember that gravity is a weak force and rethink.
I’m not sure if we know whether there is any limit to its size - but a full answer may await a quantum theory of gravity which may place new constraints on its central singularity.
There is no known or theoretical upper limit to the size of a black hole.
Black hole must be careful not to overfeed itself otherwise it could collapse to black hole. Ah-a it already is… So then it can be as big as it can feet itself.

TON 618 is the largest black hole known to humans. It is a very distant and extremely luminous quasar, an accretion disc of intensely hot gas swirling around the most massive black hole known to us. You can fit 66 billion Suns in it.

Very big, as the present answers suggest. The Universe is LARGE and so are many things in it. Past a certain “largeness” we don’t really have a grasp of size. Thus there is no answer to your question that allows us to get a sense of this.
There’s no theoretical upper limit. Given the amount of material available black holes much bigger than the big ones at centers of galaxies aren’t going to actually occur.

Black holes are theorised to be ultra-dense, collapsed remnants of burned out stars. Unfortunately this is one of the instances where the theory is unfalsifiable and therefore unscientific. “ Declaring an unfalsifiable theory to be scientific would then be pseudoscience”
In principle all the mass in the universe could go into one big black hole. But there’d have to be a mechanism for all the bits to lose their kinetic energy and angular momentum.
So far scientists have discovered in the nearby constellation, Como Bernice's that is 336 million light years away from us, a supermassive black hole of 21 billion solar masses.
Some scientist believe that we are living in a black hole. In that case the mass of largest black hole we know is the mass of the universe minus all masses of the black holes of the universe.
Black holes that have come from consuming a whole galaxy, will be around 0.1 light years. Andy Flectcher gives an example of 5885 l.y. across.
No bigger than the black hole within the mind who believes such illusions.
As big as you want, until you run out of available matter in the Universe.
I do not know of a limit on the size of a black hole.
It depends on how much matter it attracts.
